content.webTitle: Ten things we learned from Posh People: Inside Tatler

fields.headline: Ten things we learned from Posh People: Inside Tatler
fields.bodyText: 1) Posh people really, really love their dogs. One of Tatler’s best-selling issues featured a corgi on the cover. This is not just a window into the curious mind of the Tatler reader, but an explanation for why their style advice often features lines such as: “The Whippet has over taken the pug as the chic dog de jour,” and why every editorial meeting seem to include mention of a dog – “What is Tatler porn? Is it labradors gamboling?” – and why there is also a dog in the office. All of which brings up terrible memories of the events of 2013, when Alan TBH Plumptre, Tatler’s staff daschund, met an unsightly end in a revolving door. RIP, Alan. 2) “The wrong choice of tweed on a Tuesday afternoon is epically terrible”, comments one Tatler employee, in a way that makes it impossible to discern where his tongue lies in relation to his cheek. That’s the thing about Tatler, when you think they must be joking, they’re not, and vice versa. 3) Editor Kate Reardon describes herself as a “honking great Sloane”. To paraphrase a line from The Big Lebowski, that’s a name no one would self-apply – except at Tatler. 4) The hair mood board at Tatler, like the mood board for just about everything else at the magazine, is pretty much the Kate Middleton blowdry. 5) Posh people never really believe they’re posh. The reasons are obscure: commissioning editor Matthew Bell can’t be posh because he’s “half foreign”, for example. 6) As befitting a publication that hands out copies of Debrett’s Guide to Etiquette and Modern Manners to new staff members, their resident pap Hugo Bernund, instead of upskirt shots of Lily Allen, enthusiastically snaps Jilly Cooper at polo matches. “We’ve got our Hollywood A-lister, we’ve got our journalist, we’ve got our celebrity writer,” he says, running through a checklist of what’s needed for the Tatler pages – or perhaps the worst party of all time. 7) Aristos are in big trouble. As staff photographer Amelia Toubridge explains, aristos actually have to work these days. “They aren’t sitting around just reading wonderful books and playing piano all day, which is what they were doing 100 years ago.” As a result, Tatler organises a feature on poundshops, where one staff member discovers the joys of a shop where everything is a pound: “If people knew what was here it would be absolutely stuffed to the rafters.” 8) There’s actually someone on the Tatler staff called Sophia Money-Coutts (pronounced Saphia, obvs). As the mag’s staff list says, “Sophia Money-Coutts is a real person, not a made-up character”. 9) Tailcoats for the Bullingdon club are rumoured to cost £3,500 and are made at Savile Row tailors Ede and Ravenscroft, as Bell discovers when he does a feature about the secretive club for rich tossers who will one day run the country. 10) “Print isn’t dead, it just means you need to get more creative,” says one staffer, which for Tatler means giving away a paper doll of Kate Middleton which you can dress in its own Delpozo gown. Another Tatler editor notes that the Duchess of Cambridge is smart because she manages to avoid eye contact with cameras at all times, making it impossible for any magazine to ever run a picture of her on the cover that looks anything other than incidental. By Tatler standards, this is practically punk.
